projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

figure.head: DIEV ET MON DROIT
figure.figDesc: royal blazon or coat of arms

div.head: BY THE Lord Lieutenant General AND General Governour OF IRELAND.
div.p: WHereas we are Authorized and Required by His Maje≈øties Letters, bearing date the 13th. day of February, 1676, to give ≈øuch further Rules and Directions for the better di≈øpo≈øing and Settling the remaining part of the ≈øecurity of the Commi≈ø≈øioned Officers which ≈øerved his Maje≈øtie in the wars of Ireland, before the fifth of June, 1649. As we ≈øhall ≈øee nece≈ø≈øary and conductng to the better ≈øatisfaction of that intere≈øt. We have thought fit to give the following Rules to His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners appointed for ≈øetling the undi≈øpo≈øed part of the ≈øaid ≈øecurity.

Fir≈øt, That in ca≈øe the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor de≈øires to Compound for the Fee of any Lands, Tenements or Hereditaments, and it doth not appeare (otherwi≈øe than by his own di≈øcovery) that the Kings is Intituled to the ≈øame, that the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor be Admitted to have His Maje≈øties Title, and be Di≈øcharged of the mean Profits, paying one third part of the value of the ≈øaid Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, the ≈øame to be valued, viz. the Inheritance of Lands at ten Years Purcha≈øe of clear Yearly value, over and above the Quite, Rent, and of Hou≈øes, and other Hereditaments, at eight Years purcha≈øe at the like clear yearly value.

Secondly, That where there is an Incombrance, and the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor de≈øires the Preemption, and being his own di≈øcovery, there the inheritance of Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments to be valued as afore≈øaid, and the Incumbrance being deducted, the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor to pay, viz. if an Incumbrance of money by Mortgage or otherwi≈øe upon Lands or Hou≈øes, one third of the Remain of the value, and if an Incumbrance by Lea≈øe for Term of years, the Lea≈øe to be indifferently valued, and to pay one third of that value after deduction of the Ineumbrance as afore≈øaid; And if the Incumbrance be from a Nocent, to an Innocent, in which ca≈øe the Money is onely forfeited, a third part of the Money.

Thirdly, That where the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor de≈øires to Compound for the Fee of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, and by the help of a di≈øcoverer the Litle already appears, in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Di≈øcoverer vsing fir≈øt ≈øatisfied by the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor, according to former Rules, the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor to pay one moyety of the Remain according to the values afore≈øaid, yet no Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor to have any benefit of this Rule, who ≈øhall not within twenty days next after notice or warning given him by the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners, appear before them and accept thereof, without further ≈øuit or trouble.

Fourthly, Where the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor hath built from the ground ≈øince November, 1660. and him≈øelf making di≈øcovery, to Pay Ten years Purcha≈øe according to the value of the ground as the ≈øame ≈øhall appear to be worth before the ≈øaid Improvements, and where there was any former building, upon the ground which has been ≈øince pulled down, and New built or repaired, the ≈øaid Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor to pay eight years purcha≈øe, according to the value of the ≈øaid former building,

And we do hereby la≈øtly order and Declare, that in all Certificates hereafter to be pa≈ø≈øed by the afore≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners of any Mortgaged or Incumbred hou≈øes or Lands within the ≈øecurity of the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioned Officers, to any per≈øon who now is or hereafter ≈øhall be intituled to the Preemption of the ≈øame, or that ≈øhall by Canting or giving mo≈øt, come to have the Inheritance, and Fee thereof ab≈øolutely adjudged or decreed to him, The ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners to thereupon a≈øcertain and re≈øerve the Quitrents payable thereout to His Maje≈øtie, according to ≈øuch proportion as the whole value of the ≈øaid Re≈øpective Hou≈øes or Lands at the rate of Ten years Purcha≈øe, ≈øhall appear to them to exceed the unforfeiced Incumbrances thereupon, ≈øo that if ≈øuch Hou≈øes or Lands ≈øhall be of more value and near, but not a full fourth part more than ≈øuch unforfeited Incumbrances thereupon, in ≈øuch ca≈øe onely one fourth part of the Quitrent payable by the Acts of Settlement and Explanation ≈øhall be Re≈øerved to His Maje≈øtie out of ≈øuch Hou≈øes or Lands, And ≈øo in like manner and proportion where the value of ≈øuch Hou≈øes or Lands ≈øhall appear in a greater or le≈øs Proportion to exceed ≈øuch unforfeited Incumbrances thereupon, Yet ≈øo as the Rents that ≈øhall be ≈øo re≈øerved, be not in any ca≈øe le≈øs than one Fifth Part of the nex ‚Ä¢ t Quitrents payable to His Maje≈øtie out of ≈øuch Lands by the ≈øaid Arts, and that the ≈øaid Rents ≈øo to be re≈øerved, be al≈øo in all ca≈øes ≈øomething more than the Rent payable to his Maje≈øtie out of ≈øuch Lands in the year 1641. And that upon pa≈ø≈øing ≈øuch Certificate, the Rents therein to be re≈øerved be made payable to his Maje≈øtie from the Date of ≈øuch Certificate, And whereas the pre≈øent Farmers of his Maje≈øties Revenue, have declared their willingne≈øs and readine≈øs to con≈øent and agree to the moderation & abatement of Quitrents according to the proportion afore≈øaid, in all ca≈øes where the pre≈øent Proprietor or Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor of and Mortgaged or Incumbred Lands or Hou≈øes, within the ≈øecurity of the forty nine Officers, ≈øhall be willing to compound and agree for the preemption or Redemption of the Mortgages & Incumbrances thereon, & pa≈øs Letters Patents thereof with all convenient ≈øpeed, We do hereby further order, that in all ≈øuch ca≈øes the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners do acquaint the ≈øaid Farmers of his Maje≈øties Revenue of ≈øuch per≈øons as they ≈øhall thereunto Nominate or appoint, with the proceedings as for what Relates to the Quitrent which from time to time ≈øhall be made by them with any ≈øuch Proprietor or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor, & more e≈øpecially with the value the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhall put upon ≈øuch lands, in order to the a≈øcertaining the Rent to be re≈øerved thereout, to the end the ≈øaid Farmers, or the per≈øons thereunto appointed by them being ≈øatisfied therein, may agree and con≈øent thereunto, or otherwi≈øe declare rnd offer their rea≈øons to the contrary, or cau≈øes why they do not Con≈øent. And in ca≈øe any Difference ≈øhall happen between the ≈øaid Farmers & the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners concerning the valuation of ≈øuch hou≈øes or lands, or the due proportioning of the ≈øaid Quitrents, the ≈øame is as well by the ≈øaid Farmers, or tho≈øe appointed by them, as by the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners to be certified or Repre≈øented to the Lord Lieutenant, or other Chief Governour or Governours of this Kingdom for the time being, to be finally ≈øettled and determined, as upon due Con≈øideration and Examination of the matter in difference ≈øhall be by him found rea≈øonable and ju≈øt.
div.closer:
Given at his Maje≈øties Ca≈øtle of Dublin, the 16th. day of Augu≈øt, in the 29th. year of His Maje≈øties Reign, 1677.
W. Ellis. God ≈øave the King.

div.p: Dublin, Printed by Benjamin Tooke, Printer to the Kings Mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øtie; and are to be ≈øold by Jo≈øeph Wilde Book-≈øeller in Ca≈øte-≈øtreet. 1677.
